title: 103_hr2328
content: The Act titled "Public Lands Corps Act of 1993" is established for the purpose outlined in the Congressional findings. The Public Lands Corps Act of 1993 aims to conserve natural and cultural resources by engaging young men and women in the Public Lands Corps. This provides them with education and work opportunities, enhances their understanding of the environment, and helps them pay for higher education. The Public Lands Corps Act of 1993 aims to engage young individuals in conservation work to benefit the economy and environment. Many public lands and resources require rehabilitation and maintenance, which youth conservation corps have effectively carried out in a cost-efficient manner. The Public Lands Corps Act of 1993 aims to engage young individuals in conservation work on public and Indian lands. The purpose is to perform cost-effective conservation, rehabilitation, and improvement work, as well as assist government and tribal land managing agencies with research and public education tasks related to natural and cultural resources. The Public Lands Corps Act of 1993 aims to engage young individuals in conservation work on public and Indian lands by assisting government and tribal land managing agencies with research, public education, and conservation career exposure for youth. The Public Lands Corps Act of 1993 aims to engage young individuals in conservation work on public and Indian lands by assisting government and tribal land managing agencies with research, public education, and conservation career exposure for youth. Section 3 defines key terms. The Public Lands Corps Act of 1993 defines key terms such as "Corps" as the Public Lands Corps, "public lands" as lands owned or administered by the United States, and "qualified youth or conservation corps" as programs offering work for individuals aged 16 to 25. The Public Lands Corps Act of 1993 defines an organization that offers meaningful work for individuals aged 16 to 25 in natural or cultural resource settings, providing work experience, skills, education, and citizenship development opportunities. The term "Indian tribe" is defined as any Indian tribe or band. The term "Indian tribe" refers to any recognized Indian tribe, band, nation, or group by the Secretary of the Interior, including Native village corporations and groups established under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. The term "Indian" denotes a member of an Indian tribe, and "Indian lands" encompass real property owned or held in trust by an Indian tribe. The term "Indian lands" refers to real property owned or held in trust by an Indian tribe, subject to restrictions on alienation imposed by the United States. The term "State" includes various regions within the United States. A "conservation, restoration, or rehabilitation project" encompasses any project aimed at preserving or restoring natural resources. A conservation, restoration, or rehabilitation project refers to any project aimed at preserving natural, cultural, historic, archaeological, recreational, or scenic resources in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. The Public Lands Corps Program is established. Establishment of Public Lands Corps in the Department of the Interior and Agriculture for young men and women aged 16-25. Enrolled individuals must be U.S. citizens or residents, have a high school diploma or equivalent, and not have dropped out of school. The Public Lands Corps is open to individuals aged 16-25 who have a high school diploma or equivalent, or agree to obtain one, and have not dropped out of school. They will be enrolled without regard to civil service laws. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can contract with qualified youth or conservation corps for projects. The Public Lands Corps is open to individuals aged 16-25 who have a high school diploma or equivalent, or agree to obtain one, and have not dropped out of school. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can utilize the corps for conservation projects on public or Indian lands, with a preference for projects providing long-term public benefits and instilling a work ethic in participants. Projects under the Public Lands Corps Act must provide long-term public benefits, instill a work ethic in participants, be labor-intensive, prompt to start, and offer educational opportunities. All projects must align with relevant laws, policies, and management plans for public or Indian lands. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture are authorized to provide services and facilities for conservation programs, including establishing conservation centers. They may also arrange for logistical support from the Secretary of Defense. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can establish conservation centers and may collaborate with the Secretary of Defense for logistical support. Basic standards for health, nutrition, sanitation, and safety must be enforced at these centers, with the option to enter contracts with other entities for management. SEC. 5. RESOURCE ASSISTANTS. Authorization for qualified college students or recent graduates to be placed in Federal land managing agencies as resource assistants without regard to civil service laws. Participants will carry out research or technical functions as deemed appropriate by the Secretary of the Interior or Agriculture. Recruitment will be from colleges and universities. The Resource Assistant Program recruits college students and recent graduates from diverse backgrounds to work in Federal land managing agencies. The program aims to increase workforce diversity and provide opportunities for participants to gain experience in research or technical roles. The Resource Assistant Program aims to increase workforce diversity by recruiting college students and recent graduates to work in Federal land managing agencies. Existing nonprofit organizations can also fulfill the program requirements, and participating organizations are expected to contribute to expenses. Nonprofit organizations participating in the Resource Assistant Program must contribute 25% of the total costs for each intern through private funding. They are also required to submit an annual report evaluating the program's impact on the agency's mission. Living allowances and terms of service for participants are outlined in Section 6. Section 6 outlines living allowances and terms of service for participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistant program. Participants will receive a living allowance not exceeding the maximum established for national service program participants. They must agree to a specified term of service set by the Secretary of the Interior or Agriculture. Participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistant program must agree to a term of service set by the Secretary of the Interior or Agriculture, similar to the national service program. Participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistant program may receive educational benefits or awards. Each participant in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistant program is eligible for national service awards under the National and Community Service Act of 1990, subject to compliance with program requirements set by the Secretaries of the Interior or Agriculture. The specifics of award usage and amounts are determined under the relevant subtitle. The Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistant program participants are eligible for national service awards under the National and Community Service Act of 1990. Borrowers in the program may request forbearance on Stafford Loans during their service, subject to lender approval and Secretary of Education regulations. Participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistant program may receive post-service educational benefits under the National and Community Service Act of 1990. Borrowers serving in the program can request forbearance on Stafford Loans, subject to lender approval and regulations set by the Secretary of Education. SEC. 8. NONDISPLACEMENT. The nondisplacement requirements of the National and Community Service Act of 1990 apply to all activities of the Public Lands Corps and qualified youth or conservation corps. SEC. 9. FUNDING. The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture can pay up to 75% of project costs on public lands by qualified youth or conservation corps. The remaining 25% can come from nonfederal sources. No cost sharing is required for projects on Indian lands. The Public Lands Corps can receive contributions for projects from a foundation associated with a Federal land managing agency, with no cost sharing required. Additionally, the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture can fund up to 75% of project costs on public lands by qualified youth or conservation corps. Under the Public Lands Corps, the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture are eligible to receive funds for programs without restrictions from the National and Community Service Act of 1990. Authorization of appropriations is provided as necessary to carry out this Act.
